        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <!----></span>https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html"><!---->https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <span class="line"><!---->1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <!----></span>https://google.com/chrome<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com/chrome"><!---->https://google.com/chrome<!----></a><br>2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<span class="line"><!---->2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<!----></span><br>3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<span class="line"><!---->3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<!----></span><br>4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<span class="line"><!---->4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<!----></span><br>5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit->Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<span class="line"><!---->5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit-&gt;Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<!----></span><br><br>The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<span class="line"><!---->I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<!----></span>https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63"><!---->https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<span class="line"><!----> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<!----></span><br><br>Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<span class="line"><!---->Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<!----></span><br><br>While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<span class="line"><!---->While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
      
        
      <div>
        
      </div>
    <mr-description></mr-description>

        Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <span class="line"><!---->Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<!----></a>),<span class="line"><!---->),<!----></span> so we don't consider it a security bug.<span class="line"><!----> so we don't consider it a security bug.<!----></span><br><br>That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<span class="line"><!---->That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1194118#c6">Comment 6<!----></a>

          
        by

        Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <!----></span><br><br>Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<span class="line"><!---->Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<span class="line"><!---->Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

          <div class="input-grid">
            <label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            <div>
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

            </chops-button>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">
      
        <slot></slot>
      <label for="checkbox">
        <slot></slot>
      </label>

    <mr-issue-page><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {

        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;

        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }

          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems

      Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT

        <div class="main-text">
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems
          </h1>
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by

      <div class="main-text-outer">
        <div class="main-text">
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems
          </h1>
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by
            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <!----></span>https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html"><!---->https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <span class="line"><!---->1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <!----></span>https://google.com/chrome<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com/chrome"><!---->https://google.com/chrome<!----></a><br>2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<span class="line"><!---->2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<!----></span><br>3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<span class="line"><!---->3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<!----></span><br>4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<span class="line"><!---->4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<!----></span><br>5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit->Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<span class="line"><!---->5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit-&gt;Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<!----></span><br><br>The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<span class="line"><!---->I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<!----></span>https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63"><!---->https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<span class="line"><!----> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<!----></span><br><br>Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<span class="line"><!---->Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<!----></span><br><br>While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<span class="line"><!---->While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
      
        
      <div>
        
      </div>

        Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <span class="line"><!---->Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<!----></a>),<span class="line"><!---->),<!----></span> so we don't consider it a security bug.<span class="line"><!----> so we don't consider it a security bug.<!----></span><br><br>That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<span class="line"><!---->That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Some additional resources that others may find useful:<span class="line"><!---->Some additional resources that others may find useful:<!----></span><br><br>The KDE bug that implements the "x-kde-passwordManagerHint" metadata can be seen here: <span class="line"><!---->The KDE bug that implements the "x-kde-passwordManagerHint" metadata can be seen here: <!----></span>https://phabricator.kde.org/D12539<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://phabricator.kde.org/D12539"><!---->https://phabricator.kde.org/D12539<!----></a><br><br>My identical bug for Firefox is here: <span class="line"><!---->My identical bug for Firefox is here: <!----></span>https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1701974<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1701974"><!---->https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1701974<!----></a><br><br>This issue has also been reported to LastPass on BugCrowd, although the bug for that is not public at this time.<span class="line"><!---->This issue has also been reported to LastPass on BugCrowd, although the bug for that is not public at this time.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <!----></span><br><br>Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<span class="line"><!---->Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<span class="line"><!---->Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems
          </h1>
          
            Reported by
            
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      ch...@chrisegeland.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/1364981009" title="ch...@chrisegeland.com"><!---->ch...@chrisegeland.com<!----></a>
      ch...@chrisegeland.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->ch...@chrisegeland.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on 
      Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
            
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by
            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
            
          </small>
        <div class="main-text">
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems

    <mr-migrated-banner hidden=""></mr-migrated-banner>

        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <!----></span>https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html"><!---->https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <span class="line"><!---->1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <!----></span>https://google.com/chrome<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com/chrome"><!---->https://google.com/chrome<!----></a><br>2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<span class="line"><!---->2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<!----></span><br>3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<span class="line"><!---->3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<!----></span><br>4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<span class="line"><!---->4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<!----></span><br>5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit->Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<span class="line"><!---->5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit-&gt;Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<!----></span><br><br>The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<span class="line"><!---->I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<!----></span>https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63"><!---->https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<span class="line"><!----> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<!----></span><br><br>Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<span class="line"><!---->Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<!----></span><br><br>While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<span class="line"><!---->While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
      
        
      <div>
        
      </div>
    <mr-description></mr-description>

        Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <span class="line"><!---->Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<!----></a>),<span class="line"><!---->),<!----></span> so we don't consider it a security bug.<span class="line"><!----> so we don't consider it a security bug.<!----></span><br><br>That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<span class="line"><!---->That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <!----></span><br><br>Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<span class="line"><!---->Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>

        Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<span class="line"><!---->Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>

        mr-edit-issue {
          margin-top: 40px;

      </style>

            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems

            Reported by
            
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

            on 
      Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
            
          </small>
        <div class="main-text">
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems

          <h1>
            
            Issue 1194118: Security: Passwords written to disk in plaintext on Fedora KDE systems
          </h1>
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by
            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 30, 2021, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

          padding-bottom: 1em;

        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <!----></span>https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html"><!---->https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <span class="line"><!---->1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <!----></span>https://google.com/chrome<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com/chrome"><!---->https://google.com/chrome<!----></a><br>2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<span class="line"><!---->2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<!----></span><br>3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<span class="line"><!---->3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<!----></span><br>4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<span class="line"><!---->4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<!----></span><br>5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit->Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<span class="line"><!---->5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit-&gt;Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<!----></span><br><br>The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<span class="line"><!---->I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<!----></span>https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63"><!---->https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<span class="line"><!----> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<!----></span><br><br>Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<span class="line"><!---->Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<!----></span><br><br>While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<span class="line"><!---->While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
      
        
      <div>
        
      </div>
    <mr-description></mr-description>

          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <span class="line"><!---->Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<!----></a>),<span class="line"><!---->),<!----></span> so we don't consider it a security bug.<span class="line"><!----> so we don't consider it a security bug.<!----></span><br><br>That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<span class="line"><!---->That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>

        Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <!----></span><br><br>Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<span class="line"><!---->Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<span class="line"><!---->Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)

      <option value="0" selected="">

        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">

      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by ch...@chrisegeland.com (Mar 30, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->On Fedora 33 systems running KDE, there exists a process by which a password stored in the Chrome Password Manager may be written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.90 stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Fedora 33 (KDE Spin, available at <!----></span>https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html"><!---->https://spins.fedoraproject.org/kde/download/index.html<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <span class="line"><!---->1.) Install Fedora 33 KDE (I used Fedora-KDE-Live-x86_64-33-1.2.iso, installed via UEFI on a Dell Latitude 7490) and go through typical new user setup steps. Install Google Chrome stable through the RPM provided at <!----></span>https://google.com/chrome<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com/chrome"><!---->https://google.com/chrome<!----></a><br>2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<span class="line"><!---->2.) Launch Chrome, and save a password to any website into Chrome's built-in password manager<!----></span><br>3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<span class="line"><!---->3.) Using Chrome's password manager, copy the password saved in step 2 to the clipboard, and immediately close Chrome<!----></span><br>4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<span class="line"><!---->4.) Restart (or optionally shut down and turn back on) the computer using the Plasma restart menu option.<!----></span><br>5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit->Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<span class="line"><!---->5.) Log back in and reopen any text editor, such as KWrite, and paste the contents of the clipboard using any means (C-v, Edit-&gt;Paste, etc). The password that was previously placed onto the clipboard in step 2 is pasted into the text editor.<!----></span><br><br>The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<span class="line"><!---->The fact that the contents of the clipboard from step 2 (prior to the reboot) can be pasted into a text editor after a reboot is evidence that the contents of the clipboard were written to disk. On systems lacking full-disk encryption, this means that the clipboard content (ie: the password from step 2) is written to disk in plaintext.<!----></span><br><br>I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<span class="line"><!---->I have reported this issue to KDE's security team directly, and their response was that this behavior was intentional. I was told that there is a metadata flag that can be applied when copying to the clipboard (<!----></span>https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63"><!---->https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/blob/86278311d23b89322afddd98890385e2267c84cd/src/gui/Clipboard.cpp#L63<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<span class="line"><!----> but to my knowledge KeePassXC is the only application on the planet that utilizes this.<!----></span><br><br>Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<span class="line"><!---->Additionally, this bug was reported to Red Hat Product Security, originally on February 9, 2021, under incident INC1626643. Red Hat Product Security opted not to file a CVE on this issue, as they claim that the information cannot leak across a security boundary because the contents of the clipboard are stored in a user’s home directory, which is protected with file permissions of 0700.<!----></span><br><br>While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<span class="line"><!---->While this does appear to be a bug with KDE and Klipper specifically, I am reporting this issue so that Chrome can mitigate this issue by implementing the “x-kde-passwordManagerHint” patch shown above. I have also reported the same bug to the Mozilla Firefox team for mitigation using the same technique, as both KDE and Red Hat do not seem interested in fixing the issue upstream.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Chris Egeland<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
      
        
      <div>
        
      </div>
    <mr-description></mr-description>

        Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <span class="line"><!---->Since this requires a local attacker, it does not fall within Chrome's threat model (see <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-chromes-threat-model<!----></a>),<span class="line"><!---->),<!----></span> so we don't consider it a security bug.<span class="line"><!----> so we don't consider it a security bug.<!----></span><br><br>That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<span class="line"><!---->That being said, the password manager team may be interested in this, so derestricting the view and triaging to them.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report! Just to confirm: In step 3 you're referring to the "Copy password" functionality found in chrome://settings/passwords, correct? If yes, the Password Manager is dispatching to //ui/base/clipboard here, making use of ui::ScopedClipboardWriter::MarkAsConfidential() [1]. This seems to be a better place to implement the metadata hint. <!----></span><br><br>Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<span class="line"><!---->Thus assigning to the clipboard OWNERS and CCing a few folks who worked on related code.<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/extensions/api/passwords_private/passwords_private_delegate_impl.cc;l=316-319;drc=924f8039f6896058207961afaa2ee56550be817c<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>

        Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<span class="line"><!---->Correct, for Step 3, go to chrome://settings/passwords, and use the "Copy password" functionality and immediately close Chrome (so as not to trigger any clipboard-clearing criteria, such as timeouts).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
